lessonOverview.title: Unit 8 - Lesson 2
structures: A: How do you go there?
B: I go there by bike.
A: How does he/she go to the bank?
B: He/She goes there by motorbike.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six ways to travel (by bike, by motorbike, by taxi, by bus, by car, on foot) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Mime actions for “by bike,” “on foot,” etc. Students guess and say the mode of transport. Then match to SB visuals.
stretchStrategies: How Do We Get There Relay – Teacher calls out a place: “Hospital!” First student asks: “How do you go there?” Partner answers: “I go there by taxi.” Next pair continues with a new place. Creates a fast-paced speaking chain.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can ask and answer simple questions about ways to travel using “How do you go there?” / “How does he/she go to the (place)?” and respond with “I go there by...” / “He/She goes there by...”.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Ask: “How do you go to school?” Students answer using “I go there by bus.” Extend by asking about family members.
stretchStrategies: How Do We Get There Relay – Teacher calls out a place: “Hospital!” First student asks: “How do you go there?” Partner answers: “I go there by taxi.” Next pair continues with a new place. Creates a fast-paced speaking chain.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structure “How do you go there?” / “How does he/she go to the ___?” / “I go there by ___.” / “He/She goes there by ___.” to talk about transport.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) On the board, write two prompts: “How do you go to ___?” and “I go there by ___.” Practice in pairs using places from the SB.

items: Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

Certain common places will not overlap in style or popular concept with their Western equivalents (fire station, post office, bakery, library), whereas others are more comparable (hair salon, shopping centre)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
